I grew up without a dad. One day my mom, my brothers, and I were watching TV and we came across the Crocodile Hunter. From that day forward, myself and my oldest brother were hooked. We learned how to properly identify and behave around animals. We'd get wild snakes, turtles, and other animals out of the road to prevent them from accidentally killing themselves. We even rescued an injured baby falcon that the mother had abandoned (brought it to an animal rehabilitation center). All the while when I see or interact with a wild animal, I think to myself "What would the Crocodile Hunter do?" I still do this after so many years. The day Steve died, I lost my role model. I lost the man who taught me so many things. It's cheesy, but Steve was the father I never had growing up. I've had several deaths in my family and I've only ever cried for two of them. My grandpa, and Steve Irwin.

He always knew when an animal wasn’t behaving correctly !? ... smh first of all. He’s dead so no. Second, he was underwater in the ocean out of his element, and working with an animal that gives off very little cues as to what they are thinking or planning to do. I’m sure his ability to read those cues was minimal at best. The problem as I see it his lack of self awareness in the situation. Meaning he should have known he was not experienced enough to be so close to animal like that and should have let an expert in the field do the video. But his approach of being goofy to get attention superseded the number one rule... safety. I disagree with the comment it just all looked dangerous but in actuality it was carefully planned. These are wild animals and any sense of security around wild animals is false. As his fate showed, he was doing very dangerous things he shouldn’t have been doing, especially as a father, under the guise of conservation. If someone constantly put themselves in harms way UNNECESSARILY everyday and they had kids you would call them unkind words, but he is patted on the back for invoking animals primitive defense mechanisms for people’s enjoyment supposedly to teach us what not to do as if we don’t have our own built in senses.

I don't think I responded to one of your comments. How you doing? I am the manager for PROJECT STINGRAY and want to help these creatures.

My company are doing the most advanced research on these stingrays and a few other animals of course. We have just recently discovered new facts for the stingray as of this year. It is so new, that there are no articles on the internet about it...yet. The employees will soon work on a website.

Our scientists have discovered the best way to make the stingray live a longer life and die from natural reasons. "Natural reasons" as in old age.

From their research, we have discovered that millions of years ago, all stingrays were barbless. The barb and venom came from a mutated gene tons of stingray generations ago. Then, here we are today where humans think them having a barb is "normal" because that is they only way we have known them.

We can increase their natural defense by going for the tail. Well, a few of our scientists did an experiment. They went to the ocean with a tank and filled it with the ocean water and brought it to the lab. Next day, some employees went fishing and caught a stingray. We cut the tail off and threw it in the tank which was the same water he came from. Visually, we didn't notice anything. So, we got the tailess ray out of the tank and it felt harder than usual.

The stingray was slippery and a guy dropped it. However, it made a strange sound when the animal hit the floor. It sounded a little too hard, so we did some experiments. To shorten it and cut to the chase...I remember a scientist talking a hammer and hitting it on top of the stingray. It did nothing to the animal and we were all shocked.

We tested the stingray and researched it for some time. We discovered that the removal of a stingray's tail and when it is submerged in the water it came from...the skin of the animal gets tough as titanium. This has been the craziest biological discovery we have ever done. Maybe, the ray doesn't even need to be submerged into the water it came from...it may just need to be touched by the ocean water it calls home and the major defense mechanisms kick in.

If you come across a stingray or know a friend that comes across a stingray...cut the tail off. If you go fishing for them or catch them by accident, make sure to bring a knife to the coast. Be careful, don't get stung and after the tail is gone pour some of the ocean water it came from on top of the tailess animal. Then, just for a quick experiment stab the top of the ray with your knife and it will not even go through the skin at all. The most it can do is make a scratch and that is it.

A tailess stingray that is swimming in the water it grew up in can't get killed by predators anymore. Sharks can only make little marks and scratches on the stingray after it's new defense system is activated...by you or any other human that wants to help. Be the best you can be and become a hero...never give up and don't back out. The stakes are high and you can make a difference for our fellow stingray animals.

Also, I am doing these experiments myself and they have been working EVERY time. I have not killed one stingray. We are here to preserve and help mother nature...in the newest of ways.

Take care and God bless,
Kyler R.

P.S. Sorry if this was long. I am used to typing emails and letters to the staff. Oh, you can become a staff member too by doing the mentioned stingray experiments above...plus any of your friends that try it.

What a situation to have to deal with.  As a firefighter (now retired) I had to deal with the loss of three firefighters on my department when an incident went very badly one night.  That was in 1974.  Since then I joined another department and became the Hazardous Materials Specialist, the Training Officer, an Emergency Medical Technician, and so on.  I still deal that loss, but I decided to give something back.  I did my best to honor the memory of those three firefighters.  Here is an example of the very same line of thinking.  Also, it's a good thing that Steve Irwin's daughter and son are carrying on with their father's legacy.  Godspeed, Steve.

No.1, Australians are straight on, I love his honesty. But to say that we needed Steve to teach US to not be idiots is an over statement. Pay attention to your teachers. Understand chemistry, physics, and learn to use tools. Know the limits of your body. Understand the power of and that parts of nature are unmalleable. You can adulterate water, but you can't avoid breaking bones and parallelizing yourself in a bad fall onto it. Something as simple as pond slime on a rock can change your life forever. All we need to understand is that wild animals need to be respected and that they too need their space. A 50-lb deer can end your life in an instant, do you really need to drive at 40mph instead of 25mph? Do you need to hunt and kill an 80 year old/500lb alligator so you can brag about it on Instagram? Or isnt't catching five fish enough to feed your family and friends. I am perfectly happy with Justin and his friends experimenting right up to the edge. Gun silencers. Shooting an AK in a pool. Messing with Tesla coils. I don't need to do it. Understand a bit of the math and electronics is enough. Just learn to be and to let things be. Hoarding wild and crazy experiences is like galloping a horse when you could just trot through a meadow. The margin for error is continually narrower.

R. I. P Steve! You still make Australia proud!

Steve Irwin is the main reason I have so much love for, and interest in, animals today. I grew up absolutely addicted to the Crocodile Hunter. He showed us all the beauty, grace, and sheer power of animals both small and large, which most people will never be lucky enough to experience outside of television and internet videos, and you could tell in every episode, that he loved every single second of it. He adored animals, and did everything he could to protect them whilst teaching us at home who they really are, and how they should be treated. I still remember the episode when he was driving down the road, next to a field where a fire had started, and he almost started crying when he found a half-dead gecko that had be burned by the flames. He held it in his hands, with tears in his eyes, and you could literally feel his passion for these creatures. To sum it up, the world hasn't recovered from his passing, and I don't think it ever will.

Actually, you want to see a man that's great with animals? Watch David Attenborough.
Or Jeff Corwin. Animals literally come to them, not run away from them, like they did with Steve Irwin.
I also watched some of Irwin's shows, but I've never seen an episode where the animal he's addressing, didn't look like they were scared of the man, and wanted to flee. He had the heart for nature, but he didn't have the 'mojo'. Nature was afraid of the man. His energy wasn't peaceful, not like David's or Jeff's.
On the day I saw him diving and swimming around the ocean, I knew he was out of his usual element. I even predicted to my girlfriend that he was going to die underwater, because of being out of his element, and because of his erratic energy.
3 months later my girlfriend goes - did you hear what happened with Irwin? I replied right away, 'let me guess, he died'.
I wasn't at all surprised.
